p.s: Abe and Amir have a very difficult relationship that develops and changes a lot throughout the play.
Abe already gets introduced in scene two.
He is Amir's Nephewnephew, and also is from Pakistan.
Abe's parents and Amir's parents immigrated from Pakistan into America.
Amir is 40 years old, a successfullsuccessful lawyer living a wealthy life in Manhattan, New York.
Amir has fully converted into American lifestyle and society: he has a perfect American accent, dresses like an American, changed his name and even married a white woman: Emily.
One would say that he is assimilated into American society.
He completely gave up his identity and doesn't want to be associated with the Islam in any way.

He even defends the American authorities and their actions against Abe, even though they were clearly racist and completely against his religion and his heritage (Abe: ... Then they push us to start doing stuff for them.Amir: Okay..., line 11-12).
Even though Abe is also an immigrant in America, he has a very different point of view.
His opinions split with the ones of his uncle Amir, especially at the end of the play.
While Amir rather assimilated, Abe integrated into American society.
In the beginning of the play we learn that he also changed his name, just to make things easier for him here in America.
But in scene four he reveals, that he changed his name back (Abe: I changed it back!, line 59).
So one big difference between Amir and Abe is, that while Amir is constantly trying to hide his religion and deny his heritage, Abe learns to be proud of his identity and where he comes from.

Because Amir just wontwon't acknoulidgeacknowledge the unjustice in society and rather ignore it and hide from it, they split apart during the play and get into a huge fight at the end, which ends with Abe saying that he doesn't need Amir anymore (Abe: I'll handle it myself, uncle, line 75).
This shows that Abe has given up to try to change Amir's point of view and convince him to be proud of his religion and how he was raised.
One last time, he comes to him for help in a case of injustice.
But even though the case is on a relative, a family member of Amir, he still defends the American authorities.

He does not even want to be on the case and immediately calls Ken, a co-worker who works at the same lawfirm as him (Amir: I'm calling Ken, line 17, Amir: The lawyer on Imam Fareed's case..., line 19).
After already making a bad experience when defending a Muslim man, he is so scared of being associated with the Islam again that he immediately gives it out of his hands.
Abe is speechless, that Amir is so stubburnstubborn in his ways.

He starts to confront him about what he would do if he had to work for the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation, the ones that take racial actions against people with an immigration status (Abe: They're going into our community and looking for people whose immigration status is vulnerable.Then they push us to start doing stuff for them, line 10-11).
Abe gets really frustrated about Amir because he just doesn't see what is happening right in front of him.

Amir thinks Abe just does not respect him anymore (Amir: I'm still your elder.You need to show me a little respect, line 54), but in Abe's eyes Amir has forgotten who he really is (Abe: You forgot who you are, line 57).

The fight gets very intense, Abe loses control and yells at Amir (Abe: It's disgusting.The one thing I can be sure about with you?You'll always turn on your own people.You think that makes these people like you more when you do that?They don't.They just think you hate yourself.And they're right!You do!I looked up to you.You have no idea, line 63-66).
He accuses him of making things worse by hiding his identity, trying to make society accept and like him.
He also accuses him of being a bad rolemodel to him.
He probably also changed his name in the first place because Amir did so.
And last, he says that Amir's fassade is useless.
That people don't believe him and see that he actually hates who he is and what he has to become to be accepted in America.
In Abe's opinion, it is useless to hide.
You should be aware and proud of where you come from.
And if America is too much and not ready for them they just should have stayed in Pakistan (Abe: Maybe we never should've left, line 40).
But Amir is so scared and oppressed, he fights against everything Abe is saying (Amir: and to do it honestly.Which isn't an option in Pakistan, line 45).
All in all you can say that even though Amir and Abe are related, come from the same country and share the same religion, they are very different characters with very different world views.
While Amir is completely oppressing his identity, Abe learns to be proud of his heritage and does not hide anymore.
Abe still believes that Amir's mind can be changed.
Until the end, he tries to convince him that what is happening is not normal and he has to stop hiding.
But Amir is so scared, so oppressed and so stubburnstubborn, he just won't listen to Abe.
Because of that difference in their opinion, they get into a huge fight and drift apart during the play.
